block.p: Theater

''THE ADVENTURES OF MAYA THE BEE,'' told through rod and shadow puppets and a jazz score, is about a little bee who rejects toiling in the hive and flies off to pursue tastes more exotic than honey. Saturdays at 11 a.m. at the Salon Theater, 45 Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village. Tickets: $15; $7 for children. Reservations: (212) 539-6644.
Theater

''THE ADVENTURES OF MAYA THE BEE,'' told through rod and shadow puppets and a jazz score, is about a little bee who rejects toiling in the hive and flies off to pursue tastes more exotic than honey. Saturdays at 11 a.m. at the Salon Theater, 45 Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village. Tickets: $15; $7 for children. Reservations: (212) 539-6644.

THE HANDLESS MAIDEN, an adaptation by Gerald Cosgrove of a Grimm Brothers fairy tale, chronicles a young woman's odyssey through theater and dance. A Fringe Festival production geared to all ages, the play features original music as well as European folk songs and indie pop. Sunday at noon at University Settlement, 184 Eldridge Street, second floor, Lower East Side. Tickets: $12; the elderly and residents of ZIP code 10002, $7. Reservations: (212) 420-8877.

KINGS COUNTY SHAKESPEARE COMPANY'S FESTIVAL, through Sept. 3 at Founders Hall Theater of St. Francis College, 182 Remsen Street, Brooklyn Heights. In repertory: Shakespeare's ''Midsummer Night's Dream,'' tomorrow and Sunday at 8, and ''The Rivals,'' Sheridan's comedy of manners, tonight at 8. For children the highlight will be the preliminary performance at 7:15, ''Shakespeare's Clowns and Villains and Willie's Willful Women,'' featuring comic scenes from the plays, performed by the KCSC Young Company. Tomorrow and Sunday at 2 p.m., ''Midsummer in the Key of Dreams,'' featuring a hip-hop score, musicians and break dancers ages 12 to 20. Suggested donation: $5. Information: (718) 398-0546.

''THE LAND OF SMILES,'' a musical with rod and hand puppets by the puppeteer and singer Susan Delery Whedon, with characters like Gritzi the Gremlin and Freddy the Frown, tomorrow and Sunday at 11:30 a.m. and 2:30 p.m. at Papageno Puppet Theater, 462 Columbus Avenue, at 82nd Street, Manhattan. Tickets: $6. Reservations required: (212) 874-3297.

''SUMMER PLAY PARTY,'' the winners of MCC Theater's annual playwriting competition for students at public high schools in New York City. The plays are given full professional productions that involve the playwrights in all aspects of the staging. The performances, at 7 p.m., run through Sunday and are divided into two programs of four plays each. Tonight and Sunday: ''From Midnight 'Til Noon,'' by Cameron Crump; ''Goomba,'' by Angel Flete; ''Porcelain Baby,'' by Danielle Wells; and ''Book 'Em,'' by Kamar Anderson. Tomorrow: ''Family Peace,'' by Claudia De La Cruz; ''Do Me a Favor,'' by Jeremy Martinez; ''Chance at Goodbye,'' by Vilma Marte; and ''The Tropical Fish of the Apocalypse,'' by Esther Sapan. MCC Theater, 120 West 28th Street, Chelsea. Suggested donation: $5. Information: (212) 727-7765.

''THE TORTOISE AND THE HARE'' and other Aesop's fables, presented by Puppetworks, 338 Sixth Avenue, at Fourth Street, Park Slope, Brooklyn, tomorrow at 12:30 and 2:30 p.m. For ages 3 and up. Admission: $7; $5 for children; $4.25 for groups of 20 or more. Reservations suggested: (718) 965-3391.
Events

''THE ADVENTURES OF ROCKY AND BULLWINKLE AND FRIENDS,'' selections from works by the television animator Jay Ward, through Sept. 17 at the Museum of Television and Radio, 25 West 52nd Street, Manhattan. Screenings are Tuesdays through Sundays at 12:15 p.m., with additional screenings Thursdays at 6 p.m. and Fridays at 7 p.m. Through Sunday, episodes include ''Goof-Gas Attack,'' in which the intrepid heroes search for the cause of an epidemic of stupidity sweeping the country. Admission: $6; students and the elderly, $4; ages 13 and under, $3. Information: (212) 621-6800.

ANIMAL HOMES HUNT. With special guide sheets, free with admission, youngsters can search for animal homes throughout the Everett Children's Adventure Garden at the New York Botanical Garden, 200th Street and Kazimiroff Boulevard, Fordham, the Bronx, through August. The idea is to learn about the animals and their habitats from the clues on the sheet. The 12-acre garden features three mazes, a waterfall and a wetland trail. Summer hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. The best way to see the garden is with a ''garden passport'' combination ticket, which grants admission to the entire grounds, with a tram tour: adults, $10; students and the elderly, $7.50; children 2 to 12, $4; under 2, free. Information: (718) 817-8700.

ARTHUR ASHE KIDS' DAY. Todd Martin, a member of the United States men's tennis team at the Sydney Olympics, will coach children on the game, tomorrow from 9 to 11 a.m. at U.S.T.A. National Tennis Center (court 13), at Flushing Meadows, Shea Stadium exit, Queens (rain date, Sunday). Free.

CENTRAL PARK CONSERVANCY presents two workshops tomorrow from 1 to 2:30 p.m.: ''Web of Life,'' games stressing the interdependence of food chains, at the Charles A. Dana Discovery Center, 110th Street near Fifth Avenue, (212) 860-1370, and ''At Home Outside,'' learning how animals build homes and making a home from natural materials, at the Henry Luce Observatory at Belvedere Castle, mid-park at 79th Street, (212) 772-0210. Free; registration required.

DANCING IN THE PARK, the 19th annual Downtown Dance Festival presentation on the lawn of Historic Battery Park, along State Street, Lower Manhattan, through Thursday (rain date, Friday). The children's family program, on Sunday from 2 to 5 p.m., features musicians and dancers from Vanaver Caravan in a tribute to Woody Guthrie, and the Incidents Physical Theater with gymnastic dancers and performers in a story about a princess's escape from her castle. Information: (212) 807-6480. Free.

''FISH JUBILEE.'' Activities will focus on marine life in the Hudson River. There will be big-city fishing, with rod, reel and bait provided free, and workshops on the river's ecosystem, through Sunday, noon to 5 p.m. Piers 25, at North Moore Street, and 40, at Houston Street. Free. Information: (212) 533-7275.

''ART FOOL,'' Mystic Paper Beasts' tales of roving minstrels in wild costumes and masks, will be presented tonight at 6:30 p.m. in the rooftop theater at the Brooklyn Children's Museum, 145 Brooklyn Avenue, at St. Marks Place, Crown Heights. Free with suggested admission: $3. Information: (718) 735-4400.

INTERACTION, a summer acting workshop at the Sony Wonder Technology Lab, for youngsters 10 and older, exploring technology through acting, ends its summer session with free performances, tomorrow at 5 p.m. and on Sunday at 2 p.m. Youngsters in the program developed the concepts, plots, characters and scripts. The audience will see how the participants create virtual computerized backdrops on the 19-foot-high screen in the Sony Wonder High Definition Theater, 56th Street and Madison Avenue. Information: (212) 833-4698.

STONE-CARVING DEMONSTRATIONS, tomorrow from 1 to 5 p.m. at the Museum of American Folk Art, 2 Lincoln Square, Columbus Avenue at 66th Street, Manhattan, in conjunction with ''The Art of William Edmondson,'' an exhibition of limestone carvings. The sculptor Chris Pellettieri will talk about stone carving and show the various stages of sculpture. Free. Information: (212) 595-9533.
Exhibitions

''LIVING ON THE EDGE,'' an interactive exhibition about the coastal environment, today from 10 a.m. to 9 p.m. and tomorrow from 10 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. at the Queens Library Gallery inside the Queens Borough Public Library's Central Library, 89-11 Merrick Boulevard, Jamaica. Visitors can activate a 10-foot-long wave tank, design a coastal landscape by computer, alter water currents with their hands and test their survival skills as a lobster, flounder or plankton. Free. Information: (718) 990-8665.

''FROM TENT TO TEMPLE: LIFE IN THE ANCIENT NEAR EAST,'' an interactive exhibition (through Jan. 14) developed by the Jewish Children's Learning Lab, Center for Jewish History, Yeshiva University Museum, 15 West 16th Street, Chelsea, (212) 294-8330, showing the daily lives of people in Biblical times. In more than 30 displays, the exhibition challenges children to solve problems the way their biblical ancestors did, building a miniature plow, grinding grain with stones or even hunting game -- images of it, that is -- with bows and arrows ending in suction cups. The exhibition will be the setting for a family tour and papyrus art workshop on Sunday from 2:30 to 3:45 for ages 7 and older. Free with admission: $6; the elderly and ages 5 to 12, $4; under 5 and members, free.

''SEUSS!'' An interactive exhibition featuring Dr. Seuss's characters, including the Cat in the Hat, through Labor Day at the Children's Museum of Manhattan, 212 West 83rd Street. Museum hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Free with museum admission: $6; infants under 1, free. Information: (212) 721-1234. In conjunction with the exhibition, there will be storytelling tomorrow and Sunday from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. at the Top of the World, Observation Deck, 110th floor, 2 World Trade Center, Lower Manhattan. Information: (212) 721-1223, extension 247.
Zoos

''WHAT HAPPENS WHEN . . .'' What does the zoo crew at the Staten Island Zoo do when the alligator won't eat? What if the spider monkey is in a bad mood or there's a new arrival with adjustment problems? Questions like these will be answered tomorrow at 2 p.m. in the zoo auditorium. For ages 6 and older. Preregistration required. Free with admission: $3; children 3 to 11, $2; under 3, free. Free parking. The zoo is at 614 Broadway, off Forest Avenue, West Brighton. Information: (718) 442-3174 or (718) 442-3101.
